title: chore: release sdk, fvm, shared, and integration tests
body: This release includes a breaking change to the message/network context syscalls.

title: chore: update wasmtime
body: Includes some important bug fixes (that likely don't actually affect us, but still).

title: fix: allow f0 addresses to be used to generate new actor addresses
body:
This is a stop-gap to ensure that we can deploy actors when the "origin" doesn't have a predictable address.

Future work: https://github.com/filecoin-project/FIPs/discussions/388#discussioncomment-4163159

title: fix: patch funty for now
body: Upstream broke the world by yanking a version.

title: fix: BufferedBlockstore#flush should not reset the write buffer.
body:
Resetting the buffer was never advertised as a behaviour of this method.

This makes it possible to call flush multiple times to selectively flush roots during its lifetime. Selective flushes are used to flush the event AMTs as they are being produced.

title: refactor: move base-fee & timestamp into the network context
body:
Now that we have a network context, there's no need to have separate syscalls for these. We've kept a separate syscall for the circulating supply, because we'd like to restrict that to special actors...

Also, rename network_curr_epoch to just epoch.

title: feat: remove dead code
body: We no longer support old network versions.

title: EVM-891: Undo HAMT extension
body: Restores the HAMT to not have the `use_extensions` option added in https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/930, but keep the `min_data_depth` from https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/935.

title: feat: enable tracing in integration tests
Remove fuzz-corpora submodule, leave a note how to do local fuzzing
refactor: slightly rework wasm memory limit configuration
body:
- Avoid exporting `default_wastime_config` (we don't actually need to).
- Make it take the `EngineConfig`.
- Return an error if the requested memory size is not a multiple of the page size.

title: Split `InvokeContext` into two
body:
Splits `InvokeContext` into `NetworkContext` and `MessageContext` for clearer separation of capability domains (network context must be able to inspect network values, same with message/message context).

`vm` module is where i kept the message context as it doesnt really fit anywhere else and I didnt want to have it in it's own module.

!!! a test was disabled till I can merge a fix into builtin actors for dependencies of `vm::context` !!!

title: MEM-851: Memory expansion gas (to master)
body:
Resolves https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/851

This PR contains all the commits from https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/1058 cherry-picked and updated against `master`, and an additional update to point at the original test-vectors for conformance tests, rather than the v7 PR - a somewhat moot point because conformance tests on this branch are disabled until test vectors can be extracted.

TODO: 
- [x] Conclude the review of https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/pull/1058
- [x] Cherry pick any additional fixes that came out during the review
- [x] Decide on a ~non-~ zero memory gas price (NB conformance tests fail with anything non-zero ATM).

title: MEM-851: Memory expansion gas (to feat)
body:
This is a rollup of all `MEM-*` requests that were individually a bit fragmented to review. 

The PR is still opened to a feature branch because eventually to go to master we'll have to take just the gas related code, not the conformance tests which won't work on master.

title: add support for actor events.
body:
Reference implementation of https://github.com/filecoin-project/FIPs/pull/483.
Part of #1048.

## TODO
- [x] Make events AMT root in Receipt optional.
- [x] Implement gas handling.
- [ ] ~Validate that values in event entries are valid DAG-CBOR.~
	- Moved to #1082.
- [ ] ~Macro for emitting events.~
	- P3, not necessary at this stage; will be more impactful with native actors (M2.2).

title: FIX: HashBits::next when bit_width does not divide 256 and the full hash is consumed
body:
Fixes `HashBits::next` returned an error when we have consumed all but the last bits of a key, and what's left is less than the bit width. The PR changes it so that it consumes whatever is left, and only fails on the next call when the whole key has already been consumed. 

The following table shows width of the last chunk of the 32 byte long hash with various bit widths:

| bit_width | last nibble width |
|-|-|
8 | 8 
7 | 4 
6 | 4
5 | 1
4 | 4
3 | 1
2 | 2
1 | 1

The reason this probably hasn't come up before is that with hashing it's very unlikely that to keys share all but their last bits. However with the hybrid hashing+offset based strategy used by Solidity this is exactly what happens for arrays, and then some bit widths work while others don't.

title: EVM-892: Add min_data_depth option.
body:
part of https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/892 

Adds an option to the HAMT `Config` to keep the first N levels of the tree free of key-value pairs, reserved for routing links. The motivation is to reduce the write amplification we observed in https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/888

This should help with the `mapping` type that Solidity puts in random keys in the HAMT which weight down on everything by saturating the root node and then its children with data. 

Unfortunately we also want the top level variables to be easily accessible, they would be okayish to be in the root node (unless perhaps if they are fixed size arrays stored inline). This would be an awkward setting for the HAMT to have, though. Also if there are enough top level variables their keys will all look like `000...01`, `000...10` etc, so they will most likely fill the first bucket in the root node (takes 3*256 bits) and rely on the extension mechanism to keep them from going all the way down to level 32.

title: EVM-891: HAMT link extension
body:
part of https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/891

## Description

The PR adds an option to the HAMT to use _extensions_ in `Pointer::Link` to skip levels in the tree where the keys would map into the same bucket. This is not enabled by default because with the default `Sha256` hashing this is probably not an issue, and also for backwards compatibility on the CID level. It's being added to support the HAMT as a backend for the EVM, where the Solidity compiler already applies hashing on the keys plus an offset to put array entries next to each other. 

As a first step we circumvented the HAMT hashing in the EVM actor in https://github.com/filecoin-project/builtin-actors/pull/730
As the charts showed this resulted in very deep trees for arrays, where most levels apart from the bottom only contain a single pointer. This PR should see those trees shrink, the number of reads and writes go down. 

Since then we discussed that potentially the AMT would also be a viable data structure for this purpose, if it had similar skipping to what's being added here. If the EVM switched to AMT, I'm not sure how much value is in the HAMT having the skip feature. It's relevant based on the hashing strategy that the user implements.

## Changes
- [x] Add a `hamt::Config` to contain `bit_width` and a new `use_extensions` flag. Disabled by default.
- [x] If extensions are enabled, find the longest prefix in keys once a bucket is filled up and a subshard needs to be created.
- [x] During searches/deletes, check if a key matches the extension in the link. If not, don't retrieve the node from the store.
- [x] Use `Ipld::Map` for serialization of `Pointer::Link` _iff_ there is a non-empty extension in it.
- [x] Refactored unit tests to allow different HAMT configurations
- [x] Added fuzz tests for the extensions using the same corpora as the simple case 

## Notes

I saw that the `depth` was recently removed from the recursive methods, however I wanted to keep it until I can try another optimisation in https://github.com/filecoin-project/ref-fvm/issues/892

In retrospect it would have been much simpler to store the list of indexes in the `Extension` at each level, which would have made splitting easier. I decided early on to use bit packing instead based on how `HashBits` works to save storage space; if the `bit_width` is much smaller than 8 this would result in fewer number of bytes in the `path` than if we stored numbers. At the time I thought about storing indexes as `u32` which `next` returns, but that would have made no sense actually since it always fits an `u8`, so the actual difference might not be that much; definitely not with the default `bit_width` where it's identical.
